{{refimprove|date=February 2011}} {{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Fukuoka Yahuoku! Dome | nickname = Fukuoka Dome, Yahuoku Dome | image = [[Image:Fukuoka Dome 20160426.JPG|200px|Fukuoka Dome]] | fullname = | location = 2-2-2 Jigyōhama, [[Chūō-ku, Fukuoka|Chūō-ku]], [[Fukuoka]], Japan | coordinates = {{coord|33|35|43.16|N|130|21|43.48|E|region:JP_type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = April 1, 1991 | built = Early 1993 | opened = April 2, 1993 | renovated = | expanded = | publictransit = '''[[Fukuoka City Subway]]:'''
[[Kūkō Line (Fukuoka City Subway)|Kuko Line]] at {{STN|Tojinmachi}} | closed = | demolished = | owner = Hawks Town Co. | operator = Hawks Town Co. | surface = [[FieldTurf]] 2009–present
[[Astroturf]] 1993 to 2008 | construction_cost = [[¥]]76 billions | architect = [[Takenaka Corporation]] and [[Maeda Corporation]] | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor= [[Takenaka Corporation]] and [[Maeda Corporation]] | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = Fukuoka Dome (1993–2005)
Fukuoka Yahoo! JAPAN Dome (2005–13)
Fukuoka Yafuoku! Dome (2013–present) | tenants = [[Fukuoka SoftBank Hawks]] (1993–present) | seating_capacity = 38,585 (baseball)
52,500 (concert) | dimensions = '''Left Field''' – {{Convert|100|m|ft|0}}
'''Left-Center''' – {{Convert|118|m|ft|0}}
'''Center Field''' – {{Convert|122|m|ft|0}}
'''Right-Center''' – {{Convert|118|m|ft|0}}
'''Right Field''' – {{Convert|100|m|ft|0}}
'''Outfield Fence Height''': 5.84m (19.2ft) }} The {{nihongo|'''Fukuoka Yahuoku! Dome'''|福岡 ヤフオク! ドーム|Fukuoka Yafuoku Dōmu}} is a [[baseball]] field, located in [[Chūō-ku, Fukuoka|Chūō-ku]], [[Fukuoka]], Japan. Built in 1993, the stadium was originally named {{nihongo|'''Fukuoka Dome'''|福岡ドーム|Fukuoka Dōmu}} and can accommodate 38,585 spectators.{{Cite web|url=http://www.softbankhawks.co.jp/stadium/institution.php|title=福岡ソフトバンクホークス オフィシャルサイト|access-date=July 20, 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160713133752/http://www.softbankhawks.co.jp/stadium/institution.php|archivedate=July 13, 2016|df=}}{{cite web |url=http://www.softbankhawks.co.jp/news/detail/00000190.html |title=2017年度　福岡 ヤフオク!ドームの定員に関しまして |date=March 2, 2017 |accessdate= October 5, 2018 |publisher=[[Fukuoka SoftBank Hawks]] |language=ja }} With a diameter of 216 meters, the Fukuoka Yahuoku! Dome is the world's largest geodesic dome.{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.com/culture/story/20140613-spaceship-earth-a-game-of-domes |title=The story of Buckminster Fuller’s radical geodesic dome |date=October 21, 2014 |accessdate=October 5, 2018 |publisher=BBC |last=Glancey |first=Jonathan }} This is Japan's first stadium built with a retractable roof. In 2005, [[Yahoo! JAPAN]], one of [[SoftBank]]'s [[subsidiary|subsidiaries]], acquired the stadium's [[naming rights]], and thus renamed it {{nihongo|'''Fukuoka Yahoo! Japan Dome'''|福岡Yahoo! JAPANドーム|Fukuoka Yafū Japan Dōmu}} or abbreviated as {{nihongo|'''Yahoo Dome'''|ヤフードーム|Yafū Dōmu}},{{Cite web|url=http://www.hawkstown.com/eng/dome/index.html|title=Hawkstown -Hawks Town a lively and festive place 365days a year|website=www.hawkstown.com|access-date=July 20, 2016}} In January 2013, it was renamed to {{nihongo|'''Fukuoka Yafuoku! Dome'''|福岡 ヤフオク! ドーム|Fukuoka Yafuoku Dōmu}}.{{cite web |url=https://auctions.yahoo.co.jp/topic/promo/dome/p/ |title=ヤフオク! - 福岡 Yahoo! JAPANドーム名称変更のお知らせ |accessdate=October 5, 2018 |publisher=[[Yahoo! Japan]] |language=ja }} Yafuoku means [[Yahoo! Auctions]] in Japan. ==History== [[File:Fukuoka_Dome_2008-1.jpg|thumb|300px|A Hawks game in 2008]] Fukuoka Dome is the home stadium of [[Fukuoka SoftBank Hawks]] and, together with [[Hilton Hotel|Hilton]] Fukuoka Sea Hawk Hotel, is part of the Hawks Town entertainment complex. It is located near [[Sawara-ku, Fukuoka|Momochi Beach]], about 15 minutes walk from [[Tōjinmachi Station|Tojinmachi]] [[Fukuoka City Subway|subway]] station. In 2006, the stadium received an upgrade to its mono-color main scoreboard "Hawks Vision." Sharing the same nickname as its predecessor and measured at 10 m (32.76 ft) high and 53 m (173.86 ft) wide, it was one of the largest high-definition electronic scoreboards at the time, equivalent to a 2,123-inch wide-screen display. In 2010, with further addition of two 5.7 m (120.65 ft) x 33 m (108.27 ft) displays, the stadium boasted the largest total viewing area of HD display in all baseball stadia (total area 905.2sqm or 9,743.49sqft).[[List of largest video screens]] The Fukuoka Dome has hosted one game in each [[Major League Baseball Japan All-Star Series]] since its creation, including the final game of the 2006 series, where Japan was swept for the first time in the history of the event.[[Major League Baseball Japan All-Star Series|MLB completes sweep with walk-off]] In the TV series ''[[Extreme Engineering]]'', Danny Forster makes a reference to the Fukuoka Dome, saying it was said to have a "floating" field. (An indoor baseball stadium in Japan which actually has a floating field is [[Sapporo Dome]], which also hosts [[football (soccer)|football]] games for [[Consadole Sapporo]], a [[J. League]] club. However, this stadium does not have such a field.) In 2009, the older [[AstroTurf]] field was replaced with the now more common [[FieldTurf]] brand surface to reduce injuries; the Hawks players had seen far more injuries than any other team in Japan. ==Concerts== [[Michael Jackson]] performed at the stadium four times at his solo career. The first two times, Jackson performed two sold-out concerts during his ''[[Dangerous World Tour]]'', on September 10 & 11, 1993, for a total audience of 70,000 fans (35,000 per show). The second and last two times were in 1996, during his subsequent tour, ''[[HIStory World Tour]]'', on December 26 and 28, also on two sold-out concerts for 80,000 people (40,000 fans per show). [[Whitney Houston]] performed at the stadium on September 22, 1993 during [[The Bodyguard World Tour]]. [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]] performed three times at the stadium. The shows happened on 7, 8 and 9 December 1993 during [[The Girlie Show World Tour]]. The stadium also hosted [[Frank Sinatra]]'s final public concerts on 19 and 20 December 1994. The [[Rolling Stones]] played two concerts at the dome during their [[Voodoo Lounge Tour]] on 22 and 23 March 1995. [[Bon Jovi]] played a concert at the dome on May 13, 1995 during their [[These Days Tour]]. On September 18 and 19, 2000 the stadium hosted [[L'Arc~en~Ciel]] as part of their "TOUR 2000 REAL" [[Super Junior]] performed his [[Super Show 6]] at the stadium on 20 December 2014 as part of their sixth world tour, with a sold-out crowd of 52,874 people. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.softbankhawks.co.jp/stadium/ Stadium page on Softbank Hawks official website] (in Japanese) {{s-start}} {{succession box | title = Home of the
[[Fukuoka SoftBank Hawks]] | years = 1993 – present | before = [[Heiwadai Stadium]] | after = current }} {{succession box | before = [[Sahlen Field|Pilot Field]]

{{flagu|Italy}} }} {{s-end}} {{NPB Ballparks}} {{Fukuoka SoftBank Hawks}} {{2013 World Baseball Classic Stadiums}} [[Category:Buildings and structures completed in 1993]] [[Category:Retractable-roof stadiums in Japan]] [[Category:Baseball venues in Japan]] [[Category:Covered stadiums in Japan]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1993]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Fukuoka]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Fukuoka]] [[Category:Sports venues in Fukuoka Prefecture]] [[Category:1993 establishments in Japan]] [[Category:Retractable-roof stadiums]] [[Category:Fukuoka SoftBank Hawks]]

{{Infobox company | name = Gilbert Rugby | logo = Gilbert (sports equipment) logo.svg | caption = | type = [[Privately held company]] | foundation = {{start date|1823}}{{cite web|url=http://www.gilbertrugby.com/History.aspx|title=Gilbert Rugby - History - Rugby's Original Brand|author=Grays of Cambridge (International) Ltd|publisher=gilbertrugby.com}} | founder = [[William Gilbert (rugby)]] | location = [[Robertsbridge]], United Kingdom | area_served = Worldwide | industry = [[Sports equipment]]
[[Rugby union equipment]] | products = Rugby clothing (including [[Rugby shirt]], [[Rugby shorts]], [[Rugby socks]], [[Compression garment]], body armour (shoulder pads, head guards [[Scrum cap]], [[Mouthguard]]), [[Rugby boots]], [[Rugby union equipment]], luggage, [[sport equipment]]s and other athletic and recreational products | parent = [[Grays International]] | homepage = {{URL|http://www.gilbertrugby.com}} }} '''Gilbert''' is a [[sports equipment]] manufacturing brand, specialising in [[rugby union]] and [[netball]]. ==History== {{update|[[Match-XV]]|date=May 2016}} The company was established by [[William Gilbert (rugby)|William Gilbert]], a [[Shoemaking|cobbler]], in 1823, who along with his nephew, James, developed [[Football (ball)|footballs]] for the neighbouring [[Rugby School]]. In 2002, after experiencing financial difficulties following a management buyout, Gilbert was purchased by [[Grays International]].{{cite news |url=http://www.scrum.com/scrum/rugby/story/42903.html |title=Batmaker gets balls as James Gilbert is rescued |publisher=scrum.com |date=September 15, 2002 |accessdate=2008-10-16}} Gilbert have supplied an unprecedented 6 [[Rugby World Cup]]s in a row;{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2015/sep/05/rugby-world-cup-2015-what-you-need-to-know|title=Rugby World Cup 2015: what you need to know|last=Ashdown|first=John|date=2015-09-05|newspaper=The Guardian|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077|access-date=2016-04-11}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/sport/rugby/international/rwc-15-a-history-of-the-world-cup-match-ball-1.2344466|title=RWC 15: A history of the World Cup match ball|website=The Irish Times|language=en-US|access-date=2016-04-11}} starting with in [[1995 Rugby World Cup|1995]] in South Africa; [[1999 Rugby World Cup|Wales in 1999]]; [[2003 Rugby World Cup|Australia in 2003]]; [[2007 Rugby World Cup|France in 2007]]; [[2011 Rugby World Cup|New Zealand in 2011]] and [[2015 Rugby World Cup|England in 2015]]. Gilbert was the official ball supplier of the [[Rugby World Cup 2015]],{{cite web |publisher=[[The Times]] |title=How Gilbert plans to keep England on the ball |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/rugby_union/article997178.ece |date= October 20, 2003 |accessdate=2009-02-24 | location=London}}{{cite web|publisher=[[Rugby Football Union]] |title=Gilbert to supply official match ball for RWC 07 |url=http://www.rfu.com/index.cfm/fuseaction/RFUHome.England_Detail/StoryID/12648 |date=January 9, 2006 |accessdate=2009-02-24 }}{{dead link|date=January 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}{{cite web |publisher=[[International Rugby Board]] |title=Gilbert to supply balls for RWC 2011 and 2015 |url=http://www.rugbyworldcup.com/mediazone/news/newsid=2034234.html |date=5 November 2009 |accessdate=2011-10-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110907080534/http://www.rugbyworldcup.com/mediazone/news/newsid%3D2034234.html |archivedate=2011-09-07 |df= }} and is the current long-standing official rugby ball of [[England National Rugby Union Team|England]], [[Welsh Rugby Union|Wales]], [[Scottish Rugby Union|Scotland]], [[Australia National Rugby Union Team|Australia]], [[South Africa national rugby union team|South Africa]], [[France national rugby union team|France]], [[Italy national rugby union team|Italy]], [[Argentina National Rugby Union Team|Argentina]], and the [[International Federation of Netball Associations]].{{cite web |publisher=[[International Federation of Netball Associations]] |title=Gilbert - Official Ball Supplier |url=http://www.netball.org/events.aspx?id=103 |date=July 19, 2006 |accessdate=2009-02-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080314083213/http://www.netball.org/events.aspx?id=103 |archivedate=2008-03-14 |df= }} Gilbert is also the official ball supplier of the [[ANZ Championship]], the biggest netball competition in the world and also the official supplier of the [[Netball World Championships]]. Their products include the [[Gilbert Synergie]] rugby ball. In September 2014, Gilbert Rugby launched the [[Match-XV]]{{cite web |publisher=Gilbert Rugby |title=Innovative Rugby World Cup 2015 Match XV ball launched |url=http://www.gilbertrugby.com/News.aspx?pid=20140829-GIL1 |date= August 29, 2014 |accessdate=2014-08-29 | location=East Sussex}} match ball. The Match-XV ball has been developed specifically for Rugby World Cup 2015, in England. The Match-XV match ball will be used throughout the Aviva Premiership [[English Premiership (rugby union)]], [[Top 14]] and by all Gilbert-sponsored National Unions in the test matches in November 2015. ==Sponsorships== The following teams, associations and players wear uniforms and equipment provided by Gilbert: ===Rugby Sevens=== *{{flagicon|CHI}} [[Chile Sevens|Chile]] ===Rugby Union=== * {{flagicon|WAL}} [[Dragons (rugby union)|Newport Gwent Dragons]]/[[Newport RFC]] * {{flagicon|BRA}} [[Pasteur Athletique Club]] *{{flagicon|CHI}} [[Chile national rugby union team]] *{{flagicon|BEL}} [[Belgium national rugby union team]] *{{flagicon|UAE}} [[United Arab Emirates national rugby union team]] ====Players==== * {{flagicon|WAL}} [[Richard Hibbard]] * {{flagicon|FRA}} [[Thierry Dusautoir]] * {{flagicon|IRE|rugby union}} [[Sean Cronin]] * {{flagicon|RSA}} [[Jean De Villiers]] * {{flagicon|WAL}} [[Jake Ball (rugby player)|Jake Ball]] * {{flagicon|WAL}} [[Aaron Shingler]] * {{flagicon|SCO}} [[Blair Cowan (rugby union)|Blair Cowan]] * {{flagicon|ENG}} [[Matt Gilbert]] ===Netball=== * {{flagicon|AUS}} [[Australia national netball team|Australia]] * {{flagicon|NZL}} [[New Zealand national netball team|New Zealand]] * {{flagicon|JAM}} [[Jamaica national netball team|Jamaica]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{commonscat|Gilbert (company)}} *{{official}} *[http://www.gilbert-netball.co.uk Gilbert Netball website] [[Category:Sporting goods manufacturers of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Sportswear brands]] [[Category:Manufacturing companies established in 1823]] [[Category:1823 establishments in England]] [[Category:British companies established in 1823]]

{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Gozo Stadium | nickname = ''Il-Grawnd'' | image = | fullname = Gozo Stadium | location = {{Flagicon|Gozo}} {{Flagicon|Malta}} [[Xewkija]], [[Gozo]] | coordinates = {{coord|36|2|18.0|N|14|15|22.5|E|type:landmark_region:MT|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = | built = | opened = 1936 | renovated = 1995 | expanded = 1975 | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Government of Malta]] | operator = [[Gozo Football Association]] | surface = [[Grass]] | construction_cost = £819.12s.3d.http://gozonews.com/603/gozo-stadium-shines-a-bright-light/ | architect = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor= | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = Silver Jubilee Ground | tenants =
[[Gozo national football team]]
[[Gozo Football League First Division]] | seating_capacity = 1,644http://www.uefa.com/under17/season=2014/finals/venueguide/city=1718/index.html | dimensions = 102 m x 60 m (335 ft x 197 ft) }} The '''Gozo Stadium''' ({{lang-mt|Il-Grawnd t'Għawdex}}), formerly known as the '''Silver Jubilee Ground''', is the main stadium of the island of [[Gozo]], [[Malta]]. The Gozo Stadium, which is located in [[Xewkija]], seats only 1,644 people but its standing areas at each end of its main stand ensure that the stadium can hold up to approximately 3,800 people. Similar to Malta, the Gozo Stadium is the main venue of the local top division, the [[Gozo Football League First Division]], and the finals of all cups organised by the [[Gozo Football Association]] are generally held at the stadium. == History == === Early years === The stadium was erected in 1936 and as a commemoration of the Silver Jubilee of [[King George V]], the stadium was named the Silver Jubilee Ground. The stadium, which originally comprised only what is now referred to as the Xewkija Stand, costed 819 pounds, 12 shillings and 3 pence to built. A number of amenities, namely a boundary wall around the ground, dressing rooms, toilets and a bar, were added two years later. In 1975, the stadium was expanded through the construction of an opposite stand, commonly referred to as the Xaghra Stand, and in 1995 the surface of the pitch was converted to [[grass|natural turf]] and the stadium was renamed to '''Gozo Stadium'''http://www.sportinmalta.com/new-complex-at-the-gozo-stadium-inaugurated/ At that time, the stadium was rather unique in Gozo as all other pitches had sandy surfaces. The sandy surfaces have almost all gone now but the fact that these have been replaced with synthetic surf surfaces ensures that Gozo Stadium's distinction in being the only stadium in Gozo having a natural turf pitch remains intact to this day. === Recent years === In January 2007, the stadium was illuminated by floodlights for the first time as the erection of a floodlight at each corner ensured that the '''Gozo Stadium''' could also host football matches after dawn as well. Three years after, and in anticipation of Gozo's hosting of the [[VIVA World Cup]], the stadium was subject to another investment.http://gozonews.com/12379/the-latest-upgrades-on-gozo-stadium-well-underway/. The project, which costed around €340k entailed the construction of a complex behind one of the goals. The complex includes offices, four dressing rooms, two rooms for the use of referees, new toilet facilities and a garage. In 2011, the stadium was improved through the laying of a new five-a-side pitch and the construction of a parking space catering for 75 vehicles.http://gozonews.com/16187/new-5-a-side-sports-facilities-carpark-at-the-gozo-stadium/. In 2013, and with the UEFA European Under-17 Championship in the horizon, the Government allocated €500k to fund the improvement of football grounds around the island of Gozohttp://gozonews.com/37091/e500000-allocated-for-gozo-football-ground-improvements/. The Gozo Stadium was one of the beneficiaries as part of the budget was used to fund the development of further facilities at the Gozo Stadium, particularly a state-of-the art VIP Area at the enclosure. == Description == The '''Gozo Stadium''' is located at Mgarr Road, the main road connecting [[Xewkija]] to [[Victoria, Gozo|Victoria]]. It comprises two stands on each side of the pitch. The enclosure, the larger of the two, is situated on Xewkija's side and, almost by default, is referred to as the Xewkija Side. The stand, which is sliced in two by the VIP Area, is all seated and covered under a roof. Moreover, a standing area together with a bar is located at the end of each side of the stand. Opposite to the Xewkija Side is the Xaghra Side. As suggestive by its name, it is located on Xaghra's side and aesthetically speaking the stand consists of a stand running alongside the pitch, with a bar located right at the middle. The Xaghra Side is not covered from the elements and is only opened when the stadium hosts important matches and hence hundreds are expected to turn up. Both stands are accessible from Mgarr Road. == Events == === UEFA European Under-17 Championship === The Gozo Stadium was one of the three stadiums used during the Maltese hosting of the [[2014 UEFA European Under-17 Championship]]. The stadium hosted 4 group matches in all. === UEFA Regions' Cup === Aback of the [[Malta Football Association]]'s decision to have a [[Gozo|Gozitan side]] representing [[Malta]] during the [[2013 UEFA Regions' Cup|2013]], [[2015 UEFA Regions' Cup|2015]] and [[2017 UEFA Regions' Cup|2017]] editions of the [[UEFA Regions Cup]] and consequent to [[UEFA]]'s decision for Malta to host the group matches in which Gozo was drawn in all three editions, the Gozo Stadium also hosted the 9 matches played during the Intermediary Round of the three editions in question. http://www.uefa.com/regionscup/index.html === Maltese Premier League === Up to 2011, Gozo was also used to be represented in the [[Maltese football league system]] by [[Gozo FC]]. The highest point of the club's history was its promotion to the [[Maltese Premier League]] by winning the 1998/1999 edition of the [[Maltese First Division]]. All Gozo FC's home matches during their only season in the highest echelon of the Maltese football were played at the Gozo Stadium. === 2010 Viva World Cup === The '''Gozo Stadium''' was one of the two venues to host the [[2010 Viva World Cup|2010]] edition of the [[Viva World Cup]]http://gozonews.com/13597/the-fourth-edition-of-the-viva-world-cup-kicks-off-in-gozo/. Besides the opening ceremony, the stadium hosted five matches in all, namely three group stage matches, a semi-final and the final between [[Iraqi Kurdistan national football team|Iraqi Kurdistan]] and the eventual winners [[Padania national football team|Padania]]. ==See also== {{portal|Association football}} *[[List of football stadiums in Malta]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External Links== *[http://www.uefa.com/under17/season=2014/finals/venueguide/city=1718/index.html Gozo Stadium] at uefa.com [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1936]] [[Category:Football in Gozo]] [[Category:Football venues in Malta]] [[Category:Xewkija]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2017}} {{Infobox venue | name = Havelock Park | nickname = | native_name = හැව්ලොක් පාර්ක් | native_name_lang = | fullname = | former names = | logo_image = | logo_caption = | image = | image_size = | image_alt = | caption = | pushpin_map = Sri Lanka Colombo Municipality | pushpin_mapsize = | pushpin_map_caption = | pushpin_label_position = | address = | location = [[Havelock Town]], [[Colombo]], [[Sri Lanka]] | coordinates = {{Coord|6|52|56|N|79|51|59|E|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | type = Sporting complex | genre = Sporting Events, Concert | broke_ground = | built = | opened = {{Start date|1901|||df=y}} {{Cite web|url=http://www.ceylontoday.lk/34-93671-news-detail-havelock-sports-club-celebrates-100-years.html|title=Havelock Sports Club celebrates 100 years |publisher=Ceylon Today|date=27 October 2015|accessdate=27 October 2015}} | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = | operator = | surface = Grass | scoreboard = | production = | cost = | architect = | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | seating_type = | capacity = 5,000 | suites = | record_attendance = | dimensions = | field_shape = | acreage = | volume = | tenants = [[Havelock Sports Club|Havelock SC]] ([[Rugby football|Rugby]])
[[Colts Cricket Club]] ([[Cricket]])
Burgher Recreation Club | embedded = | website = | publictransit = }} '''Havelock Park''' ({{lang-si|හැව්ලොක් පාර්ක්}}) is a [[multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Havelock Town]], [[Colombo]] [[Sri Lanka]]. It is one of the oldest grounds in the country. The sporting complex is located in Havelock Town and is bordered by Havelock Road, Park Road and Isipathana Mawatha. ==Early history== Havelock Park was established in 1901 to honour Sir [[Arthur Havelock|Sir Arthur Elibank Havelock]] (1844–1908), who was the 17th [[Governors of British Ceylon|British Governor of Ceylon]] (1890–1895), by the [[Colombo Municipal Council]] (CMC). Havelock Park was originally {{convert|1.82|ha|abbr=on}} in area but in 1905 the CMC purchased an additional {{convert|2.41|ha|abbr=on}} for Rs 30,000. By 1907 [[Galle Face Green]], [[Viharamahadevi Park|Victoria Park]] (now known as Viharamahadevi Park) and the Havelock Town Park were adjudged as being the major "green lungs" of Colombo. ==Sports== During the early decades of the 19th Century, Havelock Park became the home of several sporting clubs, although one, the Havelock Golf Club, shifted to Buller’s Road (Bauddhaloka Mawatha) where the [[Bandaranaike Memorial International Conference Hall]] now stands.{{cite news|url=http://www.sundaytimes.lk/010513/sports2.html|title=Golf started on the Galle Face Green|newspaper=[[The Sunday Times (Sri Lanka)|The Sunday Times]]|date=13 May 2001|accessdate=12 March 2015}} At the northern end of Havelock Park is the public area named after the national hero, Captain [[Henry Pedris|Duenuge Edward Henry Pedris]] (1888–1915), was executed by [[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland|British]] officials for alleged incitement of [[Race (classification of human beings)|racial]] [[riots]] in 1915, which were later proven false. Adjacent to Pedris Park, is one of Sri Lanka’s oldest rugby clubs, the [[Havelock Sports Club]], which was established in 1915.{{cite news| url=http://www.timeslanka.com/2014/09/12/havelocks-sports-club-to-celebrate-centenary-next-year/|title=Havelocks Sports Club to celebrate Centenary next year|newspaper=The Times of Sri Lanka|date=12 September 2014|accessdate=15 March 2015}} On 12 September 1907 the first international [[rugby union]] match played in [[British Ceylon|Ceylon]] was held at Havelock Park between the [[1907–08 New Zealand rugby tour of Australia and Great Britain|New Zealand All Blacks]] and an All Ceylon team. The grounds were renovated in July 2012 to celebrate the club's 97th anniversary.{{cite web|url=http://www.vivalanka.com/newspage/328028ai-|title=Havelock Hurrah|publisher=Viva Lanka|date=30 July 2012|accessdate=15 March 2015}} The [[Burgher Recreation Club]] (BRC) is also located on Havelock Park. The club originally known as the Bambalapitiya Sports Club was established in 1896 and in 1901 changed to Burgher Recreation Club when the club house was relocated to Havelock Park.{{cite news|url=http://archives.dailymirror.lk/2006/05/27/sports/1.asp|title=P.M. toasts the Burghers|newspaper=[[Daily Mirror (Sri Lanka)|Daily Mirror]]|last=Rahaman|first=T.B.|date=27 May 2006|accessdate=12 March 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20150312140516/http://archives.dailymirror.lk/2006/05/27/sports/1.asp|archivedate=12 March 2015|df=dmy-all}} In the south-east corner is [[Colts Cricket Club Ground]], the home of [[Colts Cricket Club]] since 1971. The ground is a regular venue for [[first-class cricket|first-class]] matches and also hosted many [[women's cricket]] matches. The Colts Cricket Club is a [[first-class cricket]] team that has won the [[Premier Trophy|Sri Lanka domestic league]] six times, the latest being the 2011-12 season. A children’s playground was constructed in the south-west corner of the park in 1959.{{cite book|title=Ceylon Sessional Papers|publisher=Government Press|page=172|date=1962}} ==Concert== [[Romania|Romanian]] singer [[Inna]] performed at Havelock Park on 13 September 2015 in Sun FM concert SUNFEST 2015. {{Cite web|url=http://www.thesundayleader.lk/2015/08/30/sunfest-2015-sri-lankas-biggest-music-festival/ |title=Sunfest 2015 Sri Lanka ’s Biggest Music Festival |publisher=The Sunday Leader|date=30 August 2015|accessdate=23 November 2015}} [[Jamaicans|Jamaican]] singer [[Sean Paul]] performed at Havelock park on 28 November 2015 in Sun FM concert SUNFEST 2015. {{Cite web|url=http://www.sunfm.lk/sean-paul-live-in-concert-2015/press_release.php|title=Sun FM ushers in the festive season in grand style|publisher=Sun FM|date=|accessdate=7 November 2015}} {{Cite web|url=http://www.hirunews.lk/entertainment/118905/get-ready-sun-fm-proudly-presents-sean-paul-live-in-concert-colombo|title=GET READY! SUN FM PROUDLY PRESENTS SEAN PAUL LIVE IN CONCERT IN COLOMBO |publisher=Hiru News|date=22 October 2015|accessdate=20 November 2015}} [[United State of America|American]] singer [[Jason Derulo]] performed at Havlock park on 8 April 2016{{Cite web|url=http://www.hirunews.lk/entertainment/125852/jason-derulo-to-perform-in-sri-lanka|title=JASON DERULO TO PERFORM IN SRI LANKA|publisher=Hiru News|date=10 February 2016|accessdate=9 April 2016}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{Colombo|state=collapsed}} [[Category:Sport in Colombo]] [[Category:Football venues in Sri Lanka]] [[Category:Cricket grounds in Colombo]] [[Category:Sports venues in Colombo]] [[Category:Urban public parks]] [[Category:Landmarks in Colombo]] [[Category:Parks in Colombo]] {{SriLanka-sports-venue-stub}}

revision.text:
{{See also|Amateur status in first-class cricket}} {{Use British English|date=February 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2013}}
Cricket, and hence '''English amateur cricket''', probably began in England during the medieval period but the earliest known reference concerns the game being played c.1550 by children on a plot of land at the [[Royal Grammar School, Guildford]], Surrey.<ref name="A1">Altham, ch. 1.</ref> It is generally believed that [[cricket]] was originally a children's game as it is not until the beginning of the 17th century that reports can be found of adult participation.<ref>Altham, p. 24.</ref>
Originally, all cricketers were amateurs in the literal sense of the word. [[Village cricket]] developed through the 17th century and teams typically comprised players who were all resident in the same village or parish. There is no evidence of professionalism before the [[English Civil War]] or during the [[Commonwealth of England|Commonwealth]] but legal cases of the period have shown that cricket was played jointly by gentry and workers.<ref>Bowen, p. 47.</ref><ref>Underdown, p. 15.</ref>
==Amateur and professional cricketers==
In the great upsurge of sport after the [[English Restoration|Restoration]] in 1660, cricket flourished because so many people had encountered it as children, especially at school.<ref name="Bp10">Birley, p. 10.</ref> Although the sport was popular, its evolution into a major sport was accelerated by gambling because, along with horse racing and prizefighting, cricket soon attracted the attention of those who were seeking to make wagers.<ref name="Bc2">Birley, ch. 2.</ref>
To boost their chances of winning, some gamblers formed their own county-class teams such as [[Kent county cricket teams|Kent]] and [[Surrey county cricket teams|Surrey]] who played each other in 1709.<ref>[[G. B. Buckley]], ''Fresh Light on Pre-Victorian Cricket'', Cotterell, 1937, p. 1.</ref> Patrons like [[Edwin Stead]], the [[Charles Lennox, 2nd Duke of Richmond|Duke of Richmond]] and [[Sir William Gage, 7th Baronet|Sir William Gage]] captained their teams and it was gentlemen like these, and the friends whom they invited to play, who began cricket's amateur tradition, while some players were paid a fee for taking part and this was the beginning of professionalism.<ref name="Bc2"/> Thus, a Sussex team of the 1720s might be captained by Richmond and include not only additional gentlemen like Gage but also professionals like [[Thomas Waymark]]; and this was the pattern of first-class English teams for a period of 300 years from the 1660s to the 1960s.<ref>Marshall.</ref> Waymark, for example, was employed by the Duke of Richmond as a groom and this became a common arrangement between patron and professional.<ref>Waghorn, p. 7.</ref> Later in the 18th century, professionals like [[Edward "Lumpy" Stevens]] and [[John Minshull]] were employed by their patrons as gardeners or gamekeepers.<ref>Haygarth, p. 44 and pp. 98–99.</ref> But in the longer term, the professional became an employee of his club and the beginnings of this trend could be observed in the 1770s when [[Hambledon Club|Hambledon]] paid match fees to its players.<ref>''Barclays World of Cricket'', Collins, 1980, {{ISBN|0-00-216349-7}}, pp. 3–5.</ref>
The original [[Lord's Old Ground|Lord's]] was opened in 1787 and was intended to be the private preserve of a gentlemen's club which soon reconstituted itself as [[Marylebone Cricket Club]] (MCC).<ref>Birley, p. 47.</ref> Only a gentleman could become a member but the club from its very beginning employed or contracted professionals. Lord's immediately began to stage major matches and these attracted the crowds that some members had originally sought to avoid. MCC teams soon adopted the now age-old formula of "gentlemen" and "players" in the same team.<ref>Haygarth, pp. 106–107. The MCC v [[Middlesex county cricket teams|Middlesex]] match at Lord's in 1790 featured 11 professionals with [[William Beldham]] and [[Robert Clifford (cricketer)|Robert Clifford]] playing in the MCC team.</ref>
==Growth of cricket in the schools and universities==
There are few 17th century references to cricket being played at or in the vicinity of schools, but the sport was played by pupils at [[Eton College]] and [[Winchester College]] by the time of the [[Commonwealth of England|Commonwealth]].<ref name="B1">Birley, ch. 1.</ref> There is a reference to the game at [[St Paul's School, London]] about 1665 concerning [[John Churchill, 1st Duke of Marlborough]], who studied there.<ref name="Bp10"/>
In his ''Social History of English Cricket'', [[Derek Birley]] comments that school cricket was "alive and well during the interregnum" (1649–1660) and speculates that the game "must have been known to every schoolboy in the south-east" of England.<ref name="B1"/> However, he doubts that the sport at this time was part of any school's curriculum. Apart from Eton and [[Westminster School]], all schools in the 17th century had local intakes and no class segregation. Therefore, the sons of rich and poor families played together.<ref name="B1"/>
In 1706, [[William Goldwin]] (1682–1747) published his ''Musae Juveniles'', which included a Latin poem called ''In Certamen Pilae'' (On a Ball Game). This has 95 lines and is about a rural cricket match. Goldwin himself attended Eton and then graduated to King's College, Cambridge in 1700. It is almost certain that he encountered cricket at both establishments.<ref>Altham, pp. 24–25.</ref> There is a reference to cricket at [[Cambridge University]] in 1710 while [[Samuel Johnson]] recorded that he played cricket at [[Oxford University]] in 1729.<ref>Major, p. 45.</ref> In 1760, the Reverend James Woodforde played for "the Winchester against the Eaton (''sic'')" at Oxford.<ref name="B33">Birley, p. 33.</ref>
[[Horace Walpole]] entered Eton in 1726 and later wrote that "playing cricket as well as thrashing bargemen was common".<ref>Birley, p. 15.</ref> The Sackville family which produced the Dukes of Dorset, most notably [[John Frederick Sackville, 3rd Duke of Dorset|the 3rd Duke]], sent its sons to Westminster, the 1st Duke studying there at the end of the 17th century; and it was through playing cricket at school that the game became a Sackville family tradition.<ref name="A66">Altham, p. 66.</ref><ref name="B35">Birley, p. 35.</ref>
The spread of cricket to the northern counties by 1750 was partly due to "its transmission by interested clergy, schoolmasters and others educated at southern boarding schools".<ref>Birley, p. 29.</ref> In the middle part of the 18th century, games involving teams of ''alumni'' became popular. These fixtures ranged from a team of Old Etonians playing the Gentlemen of England in 1751 to a game at the newly opened [[Lord's Old Ground]] in 1788 which was entitled "Gentlemen Educated at Eton ''versus'' The Rest of the Schools".<ref name="A66"/> The [[first school cricket match]] which has been recorded was in 1794 between Westminster School and [[Charterhouse School]] with pupils playing as City of London and City of Westminster at Lords Old Ground. Westminster School played its games at Tothill Fields, which was where Vincent Square now stands. It is known to have played matches against Eton in 1792 and 1796.<ref name="A66"/>
Birley recorded that the "sharpest rivalry" in the middle to late 18th century was between old boys of Eton and Westminster, as these were the two oldest public schools.<ref name="B33"/> Notable cricketing patrons who attended those schools include the 3rd Duke of Dorset (Winchester), the [[Charles Bennet, 4th Earl of Tankerville|4th Earl of Tankerville]] and the [[George Finch, 9th Earl of Winchilsea|9th Earl of Winchilsea]] (both Eton). Their fellow patron [[Sir Horatio Mann, 2nd Baronet|Sir Horatio Mann]] attended [[Charterhouse School]], an indication that cricket was gaining acceptance at many other schools.<ref name="B35"/> By 1800, it was firmly established in all public and most grammar schools.<ref name="A67">Altham, p. 67.</ref>
The most important of these "many other schools" was [[Harrow School|Harrow]], which would develop a great cricketing tradition during the 19th century and produce numerous quality players.<ref name="A67"/> Harrow had formerly been a grammar school but by the end of the 18th century it had become a public school. Cricket was welcomed at Harrow as elsewhere because it was seen as a useful method for keeping the boys occupied and out of mischief, this despite its strong gambling associations.<ref name="A67"/>
==Amateurism from 1805 to 1863==
===Schools cricket from 1805 to 1863=== Eton and Harrow definitely played each other in 1805 and there is evidence suggesting a game in 1804, perhaps sooner.<ref name="A67"/> The 1805 [[Eton v Harrow]] game at Lord's seems to have been organised by the boys themselves, not by the schools, and [[Lord Byron]], who played for Harrow, is believed to have hired the venue.<ref>Birley, pp. 53–54.</ref> These two schools eventually developed a fierce rivalry that has become the schools cricket equivalent of Cambridge v Oxford or Yorkshire v Lancashire, but they did not meet again until 1818 (twice) and 1822; after that, the fixture has occurred annually except for 1829–1831, 1856 and in wartime.<ref name="A67"/> [[James Pycroft]] in ''The Cricket Field'' commented on the betting at the 1825 game but, by 1833, the match had become a social highlight and ''[[The Times]]'' noted "upwards of thirty carriages containing ladies".<ref name="B68">Birley, p. 68.</ref> Also by this time, the main public schools had grouped themselves into an elite circle and all other schools were decidedly viewed as second class by comparison. The elite were Charterhouse, Eton, Harrow, [[Rugby School|Rugby]], [[Westminster School|Westminster]] and [[Winchester School|Winchester]].<ref name="B68"/>
Among prominent amateurs of the Napoleonic period, [[E. H. Budd]] was an Etonian and [[William Ward (cricketer, born 1787)|William Ward]] was a Wykehamist (i.e., a Winchester pupil). Other noted "old boys" were [[Edward Grimston (St Albans MP)|Edward Grimston]], [[Charles Harenc]], [[Charles Wordsworth]] (all Harrow), [[John Kirwan (cricketer)|John Kirwan]], [[Herbert Jenner]] (both Eton) and [[William Meyrick]] (Winchester).<ref name="A68">Altham, p. 68.</ref>
Ward's old school of Winchester was the main challenger to Eton and Harrow. Harrow v Winchester was first played in 1825 and Eton v Winchester in 1826. Winchester won both of those games convincingly.<ref name="A68"/> [[H. S. Altham]] records that "there was a great public school festival at Lord's until its demise in 1854" which involved Eton, Harrow and Winchester.<ref name="A111"/> Meanwhile, of 234 "blues" awarded by Cambridge and Oxford from 1827 to 1854, 140 went to pupils of these three schools.<ref name="A111">Altham, p. 111.</ref>
According to Pycroft, Winchester had the best players in the 1820s and 1830s for, at Oxford, their former pupils challenged and defeated the rest of the university and they also won a match against the combined universities at Lord's.<ref name="B68"/> Six Wykehamists played in the inaugural [[The University Match (cricket)|varsity match]] in 1827 but the main participants in this were [[Charles Wordsworth]] of Harrow and [[Herbert Jenner]] of Eton.<ref>Altham, pp. 68–69.</ref> [[Charles Harenc]] of Harrow became the best amateur bowler of the 1830s. Notable Etonians of the time included [[Harvey Fellows]] and the fearsome pace bowler [[Walter Marcon]].<ref name="B69">Birley, p. 69.</ref>
The 1820s and 1830s saw the beginning of "[[Muscular Christianity]]" in the public schools.<ref name="B68"/> Dr [[Thomas Arnold]] at Rugby is often considered the "founder" of this movement but in terms of cricket it was at Winchester that the best effect was achieved, especially in their athletic approach to fielding.<ref name="B68"/> Although this was hyped as something new, there are plenty of references to outstanding athletic fielders in the 18th century such as [[Thomas Waymark]], [[John Small (cricketer)|John Small]], [[Thomas Taylor (cricketer)|Tom Taylor]] and [[William Yalden]].<ref>[[Ashley Mote]], ''John Nyren's "The Cricketers of my Time"'', Robson, 1998</ref><ref name=GDC>[[Ashley Mote]], ''The Glory Days of Cricket'', Robson, 1997</ref>
The earliest references to cricket at [[Rugby School]] and Charterhouse date from the 1820s. Other schools that gained mention in the 19th century include [[Addiscombe Military Seminary]], [[Cheltenham College]], [[Clifton College]], [[Malvern College]], [[Marlborough College]], [[Merchant Taylors' School, Northwood|Merchant Taylors' School]], [[Repton School]], [[Shrewsbury School]], [[Tonbridge School]], [[Uppingham School]], [[Wellington School, Somerset|Wellington]] and [[Whitgift School]].<ref name="A111"/>
===Gentlemen v. Players from 1806 to 1863=== {{main|Gentlemen v Players}} [[File:Gents-v-Players-1899.jpg|right|frame|Gentlemen, captained by W. G. Grace, ''versus'' Players, [[Lord's]] 1899]] The fixture that became the definitive expression of a cricketing class divide was first contested in 1806 when the two teams met twice.<ref name="A69">Altham, p. 69.</ref> Even then, the amateurs realised they were at a real disadvantage and so their team in the inaugural match at Lord's included two of the greatest professional players, [[William Beldham]] and [[William Lambert (cricketer, born 1779)|William Lambert]] as "given men". Lambert made 57 out of 195 and, given the support he received from [[Thomas Assheton Smith II|T. A. Smith]], who scored 48, his contribution ensured that the Gentlemen won by an innings and 14 runs. The Gentlemen team was actually quite good as it also included [[Lord Frederick Beauclerk|Beauclerk]], [[John Willes (cricketer)|John Willes]], [[Edward Bligh (Irish politician)|Edward Bligh]], [[George Leycester]] and [[Arthur Upton]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://static.espncricinfo.com/db/ARCHIVE/1800S/1806/ENG_LOCAL/GENTLEMEN_PLAYERS_07-09JUL1806.html |publisher=ESPNcricinfo |title=Gentlemen v Players 1806 (I) |accessdate=4 August 2015}}</ref> In the second match, Beldham went back to the Players and only Lambert was a given man. Lambert again had an outstanding game and the Gentlemen won by 82 runs, though it was Beauclerk's first innings score of 58 from only 96 that was decisive.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://static.espncricinfo.com/db/ARCHIVE/1800S/1806/ENG_LOCAL/GENTLEMEN_PLAYERS_21-25JUL1806.html |publisher=ESPNcricinfo |title=Gentlemen v Players 1806 (II) |accessdate=4 August 2015}}</ref>
The fixture was tried again in 1819 without much success and then, to quote Birley, it "struggled on".<ref name="B67">Birley, p. 67.</ref> One of the least auspicious occasions was in 1821 when the Gentlemen "gave up" after they had scored only 60 and the Players had reached 270–6. Birley states that this was a Coronation Match to celebrate the accession of the much-maligned [[George IV of the United Kingdom|King George IV]] and that "it was a suitably murky affair!"<ref name="B67"/>
In 1822, the Gentlemen did manage to win on level terms thanks to their triumvirate of great batsmen: Beauclerk, Budd and Ward. Budd scored 69 out of 138 in the first innings; Beauclerk and Ward built an unbeaten partnership in the second to secure the six wicket win; and really the Players were rather let down by their batting. Having good batsmen and ordinary bowlers was to become a Gentlemen tendency. The Players on the other hand were usually strong in bowling and generally good in batting.<ref name="A69"/>
From 1824 to 1837, the fixture was usually an odds match, the Gentlemen having as many as 18 in 1836. In two matches, the Players were handicapped by different stump lengths.<ref name="A69"/> In 1835, the Gents had [[Sam Redgate]] as a given man and he caused a stir by clean bowling [[Fuller Pilch]] twice for nought.<ref name="B68"/> In 1836, the great [[Alfred Mynn]] played for the Gents for the first time along with [[Alfred Lowth|Alfred "Dandy" Lowth]], another noted speed merchant even though he was still a 17-year-old Winchester school boy; his promising career was cut short due to failing eyesight.<ref name="B68"/><ref name="A70">Altham, p. 70.</ref>
By 1841, the fixture was in disrepute and MCC refused to organise it. It was only through the efforts of [[Charles Taylor (cricketer, born 1816)|C. G. Taylor]] and the [[Frederick Ponsonby, 6th Earl of Bessborough|Hon. F. Ponsonby]] that the game could take place. They opened a subscription list to avert its collapse.<ref name="A69"/>
===University cricket from 1827 to 1863=== The first [[The University Match (cricket)|University Match]] between [[Cambridge University Cricket Club|Cambridge University]] and [[Oxford University Cricket Club|Oxford University]] took place at Lord's on 4 June 1827. The result was a draw. The captains were Charles Wordsworth (Oxford) and Herbert Jenner (Cambridge).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://static.espncricinfo.com/db/ARCHIVE/1820S/1827/ENG_LOCAL/OX-UNIV_CAMB-UNIV_UNIV_04-05JUN1827.html |publisher=ESPNcricinfo |title=CU v OU 1827 |accessdate=4 August 2015}}</ref> It became an annual fixture in 1838.
Cambridge and Oxford were the only English universities until 1828, when the first college at [[London University]] was founded. [[Durham University]] was the fourth in 1832 and the first "redbrick" was [[Owens College]] at Manchester in 1851.<ref>Birley, p. 366.</ref>
About the early days of the two university clubs, H. S. Altham (himself an Oxford "blue") states that OUCC played on "that part of Cowley Common that was called the Magdalen Ground, so-called because it had been appropriated by the Magdalen College Choir School, whose headmaster made it over" (to OUCC). Cowley Common is in fact some distance from the University itself and so "the cricketers used to enjoy a ride out across the fences!" OUCC moved to [[The Parks]], its present venue, in 1881.<ref name="A113">Altham, p. 113.</ref>
Altham says that CUCC began at a huge public area called [[Parker's Piece]] but then became tenants at [[Fenner's]] in 1846. The club secured the lease of Fenner's in 1873. [[Francis Fenner]] had been a bowler with the [[Cambridgeshire CCC|Cambridge Town Club]] (CTC) and had acquired his land in 1846, perhaps for the express purpose of leasing it to CUCC. CTC and the subsequent [[Cambridgeshire CCC]] also played on Parker's Piece.<ref name="A113"/>
Playing standards at the two university clubs were ordinary until the 1860s. Altham admits that many CUCC and OUCC players were selected for the Gentlemen but points out that this owed "less to the strength of the universities than to the weakness of amateur cricket as a whole".<ref name="A114">Altham, pp. 114–116.</ref>
Noted CUCC players of the period include: [[Charles Taylor (cricketer, born 1816)|C. G. Taylor]]; [[Robert Broughton (cricketer)|Robert Broughton]], who was an outstanding cover point; [[George Boudier]]; [[Robert Turner King|Robert T. King]], an all-rounder who had an outstanding season in 1849; [[Frederick Ponsonby, 6th Earl of Bessborough|Hon. F. Ponsonby]]; [[Joseph McCormick (cricketer)|Joseph McCormick]]; [[Joseph Makinson]], who played for [[Lancashire CCC]]; [[George Edward Cotterill]]; [[Herbert Marshall (cricketer)|Herbert Marshall]]; [[Arthur Daniel]]; [[Charles Lyttelton, 8th Viscount Cobham|Hon. C. G. Lyttelton]]; [[Edward Sayres]]; John Kirwan; [[Edward Blore (cricketer)|Edward Blore]]; [[Robert Lang (cricketer)|Robert Lang]].<ref name="A114"/>
Noted OUCC players of the period include: Hon. [[Robert Grimston (cricketer)|Robert Grimston]]; [[Villiers Smith]]; [[Charles Coleridge]]; [[Reginald Hankey]]; [[Charlton Lane]]; the twins [[Arthur Payne (cricketer)|Arthur]] and [[Alfred Payne (cricketer, born 1831)|Alfred Payne]]; [[Walter Fellows]]; [[Richard Mitchell (cricketer)|Richard Mitchell]], an outstanding batsman at Oxford who went on to greater things as coach at Eton in the 1870s; [[Alfred Lowth]]; [[George B. Lee]]; [[Henry Moberly]]; [[Charles Willis]]; [[Gerald Yonge]]; [[C. D. B. Marsham]].<ref name="A114"/>
===The All-England Eleven=== In the middle of the 19th century, [[William Clarke's All-England Eleven]] (AEE) was a highly successful all-professional venture which did much to popularise the game. The earliest overseas tours were also all-professional affairs.<ref>Gibson, ch. 1.</ref> It was not long before amateurs became involved in the AEE.
==See also== * [[Amateur status in first-class cricket]] * [[Gentlemen v Players]] * [[Yorkshire captaincy affair of 1927]]
==References== {{reflist|2}}

S.|authorlink=Harry Altham |title=A History of Cricket, Volume 1 (to 1914) |year=1962 |publisher=George Allen & Unwin}} * {{cite book |last=Birley|first=Derek|authorlink=Derek Birley |title=A Social History of English Cricket |year=1999 |publisher=Aurum}} * {{cite book |last=Bowen|first=Rowland|authorlink=Rowland Bowen |title=Cricket: A History of its Growth and Development |year=1970 |publisher=Eyre & Spottiswoode}} * {{cite book |last=Gibson|first=Alan|authorlink=Alan Gibson |title=The Cricket Captains of England |year=1989 |publisher=The Pavilion Library |isbn=1-85145-390-3}} * {{cite book |last=Haygarth|first=Arthur|authorlink=Arthur Haygarth |title=Scores & Biographies, Volume 1 (1744–1826) |year=1862 |publisher=Lillywhite}} * {{cite book |last=Major|first=John|authorlink=John Major |title=More Than a Game |year=2007 |publisher=HarperCollins |isbn=978-0-00-718364-7}} * {{cite book |last=Marshall|first=John|title=The Duke Who Was Cricket |year=1961 |publisher=Frederick Miller Ltd}} * {{cite book |last=Underdown|first=David|authorlink=David Underdown |title=Start of Play |year=2000 |publisher=Allen Lane}} * {{cite book |last=Waghorn|first=H. {{Orphan|date=July 2011}}
'''Home ultrasound''' is the provision of [[therapeutic ultrasound]] via the use of a portable or home [[ultrasound]] machine. This method of medical ultrasound therapy can be used for various types of [[pain relief]] and [[physical therapy]].
In physics, the term "ultrasound"<ref>https://books.google.com/books?id=vY5rXC4xlMgC&pg=PA288&lpg=PA288&dq=1mhz+ultrasound+wavelength&source=bl&ots=xX03F7uI5C&sig=_6LD38Vx-BWnYk__6jO0MyG2d5M&hl=en&ei=D57MTOOmN8KB8gaxiLyzAQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8&ved=0CDgQ6AEwBw#v=onepage&q&f=fal</ref> applies to all acoustic energy with a frequency above the audible range of human hearing. The audible range of sound is 20 hertz – 20 [[kilohertz]]. Ultrasound frequency is greater than 20 kilohertz.
== Home ultrasound machines ==
Ultrasound energy is transferred based on the frequency and power output of the ultrasonic waves that an ultrasound machine or device creates. Home ultrasound machines and doctor's office machines both operate between 1 and 5 [[megahertz]], however, home machines utilize [[Pulse wave|pulsed]] ultrasonic waves while professional ultrasound machines in a doctor's office use [[Continuous wave|continuous]] waves.
Typically, when using a home ultrasound machine, you will use it more frequently than if you were to have ultrasound treatments at a therapist's office, but the end results are the same as if using a continuous wave machine less frequently. Treatments towards a pre-workout in deep muscles and relieving tendons such as arthritis, frozen shoulder, strains, and sprains.
== Home ultrasound benefits ==
Home ultrasound machines may have several benefits: long-term cost savings, portable physical therapy treatment, long-term pain relief for multiple symptoms, possible decrease in healing time, and can reduce chronic inflammation. Increase in knee range of motion after use for an injury's such as Osteoarthritis [[Osteoarthritis|OA]], which is the most common joint disorder and incidence increases with age. treatment of OA aims to reduce joint pain and stiffness, preserve and improve the joint mobility. The benefits have improvements for pain, function, and quality of life scales were effected by ultrasounds.
== Different types of ultrasound therapy ==
Home ultrasound machines operate within the range of frequencies of therapeutic ultrasound, as opposed to the more commonly known diagnostic ultrasound, or [[Diagnostic ultrasound|Diagnostic sonography]]. Typical diagnostic ultrasound machines operate in the frequency range of 2-18 megahertz, whereas home ultrasound machines and therapeutic ultrasound machines operate in the frequency range of .7-3.3 megahertz. Diagnostic sonography is typically used to create an audio "image", such as during pregnancy to visualize the developing baby.
== Home ultrasound and phonophoresis ==
[[Phonophoresis]], also known as [[sonophoresis]], is the use of ultrasound to enhance the delivery of topically applied drugs. Home ultrasound allows the application of topically applied analgesics and anti-inflammatory agents through the therapeutic application of ultrasound. It is widely used in hospitals to deliver drugs through the skin. Pharmacists compound the drugs by mixing them with a coupling agent (gel, cream, ointment) that transfers ultrasonic energy from the ultrasound transducer to the skin. The ultrasound potentially enhances drug transport by cavitation, microstreaming, and heating.<ref>http://ptjournal.apta.org/content/75/6/539.full.pdf</ref>
== Home ultrasound and pregnancy ==
The ultrasonic wavelengths create an audio "image" as the machine therapeutically shows a baby growth inside the genetic mother's uterus. They serve as a monitor and have a validation of the predictions of ovulation and the IUI [[Intrauterine insemination]] cycles.
== Variety of Home ultrasounds ==
There are home ultrasounds available for purchase prices ranging from 46.00 U.S. dollars to 5,000.00. Most popular home ultrasound buys are Roscoe Medical US 1000 portable ultrasound, SonoScape A6, Acclaim US PRO 2000, UltraTENS, and dynatron.

The '''Jim Piggott Memorial Trophy''' is awarded annually to the top rookie in the [[Western Hockey League]].
The award is named after [[Jim Piggott]] who was the founder of the WHL's [[Saskatoon Blades]], as well as one of the first presidents of the league.

{{Infobox football club | clubname = Laureles F.C. | image = | fullname = Laureles Fútbol Club | nickname = ''Albiverdes'', ''Raneros'' | founded = September 6, 1907| | ground = [[Parque Pablo Enrique Abbate]]
[[Fray Bentos]], [[Uruguay]]| capacity = 1,200 | chairman = Sebastián Roldán | manager = ? | league = [[Liga Departamental de Fútbol de Río Negro]]| season = | position = | website = http://www.laurelesfc.com.uy | }} '''Laureles Fútbol Club''' is a [[football (soccer)|football]] club from [[Fray Bentos]] in [[Uruguay]]. It was established on September 6, 1907. In 1913 it joined the [[Liga Departamental de Fútbol de Río Negro]].[https://web.archive.org/web/20071213015159/http://www.futboldelinterior.com/guia/liga-fraybentos.html Liga Departamental de Fútbol de Río Negro (Fray Bentos)] The "Laureles" is notable for its secular rivalry with the [[Club Atlético Anglo]].[http://www.laurelesfc.com.uy/SabiaUd/clasicoAnglo.html One of the oldest football derbies in the world] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303212712/http://www.laurelesfc.com.uy/SabiaUd/clasicoAnglo.html |date=2016-03-03 }} (in Spanish) ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://estadiosdeuruguay.blogspot.com/2011/05/laureles-futbol-club.html Laureles Sports Complex] * [http://www.laurelesfc.com.uy/Juveniles/sub18Campeonato.html Pictures] [[Category:Football clubs in Uruguay]] [[Category:Association football clubs established in 1907]] [[Category:1907 establishments in Uruguay]] [[Category:Fray Bentos]] {{Uruguay-footyclub-stub}}

The '''May Bumps''' (also '''May Races''', '''Mays''') are a set of [[Sport rowing|rowing]] races, held annually on the [[River Cam]] in [[Cambridge]]. They began in 1887 after separating from the [[Lent Bumps]], the equivalent bumping races held at the end of February or start of March. Prior to the separation there had been a single set of annual bumps dating from its inception in 1827.<ref name="bumps">John Durack, George Gilbert & Dr John Marks, ''The Bumps: An Account of the Cambridge University Bumping Races 1827–1999'', 2000. {{ISBN|0-9538475-1-9}}.</ref> The races are open to all college boat clubs from the [[University of Cambridge]], the University Medical and Veterinary Schools and [[Anglia Ruskin Boat Club]]. The May Bumps takes place over four days (Wednesday to Saturday) in mid-June and is run as a [[bumps race]].
The most recent in the series was the [[May Bumps 2018]], which ran from 13 June 2018 until 16 June 2018. [[File:May Bumps 2005 Day2.jpg|thumb|[[First and Third Trinity Boat Club|1st & 3rd Trinity II]] about to bump [[Caius Boat Club|Caius II]] to go top of the 2nd division on day 2 of the [[May Bumps 2005|2005 May Bumps]].]]
== Structure of the May Bumps == {{main|Bumps race}} [[File:Downing College Boat Club getting bumped May Bumps 2006.jpg|thumb|right|[[Downing College Boat Club|Downing II]] getting bumped by [[Fitzwilliam College Boat Club|Fitzwilliam]] during the [[May Bumps 2006]].]] The races are run in divisions, each containing 17 crews. The number of crews in each bottom division varies yearly depending on new entrants.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.cucbc.org/mays/gor | title=May Bumps Getting-On Race | publisher=[[Cambridge University Combined Boat Clubs]] | accessdate=April 11, 2012}}</ref> Each crew contains 8 rowers and one coxswain. A total of 154 crews took part in 2014, totalling around 1390 participants. There are currently 6 divisions for men's crews (referred to as M1, M2....M6) and 4 divisions for women's crews (similarly W1-W4). The divisions represent a total race order with Division 1 at the top. The ultimate aim is to try and finish ''Head of the River'' (also said as gaining the 'Headship'), i.e. 1st position in division 1.
At the start, signalled by a cannon, each crew is separated by a distance of about 1½ boat lengths (approximately 30m or 90'). Once the race has begun, a crew must attempt to catch up with the crew ahead of it and ''bump'' (physically touch or overtake) it before the crew behind does the same to them. A crew which bumps or is bumped must pull to the side of the river to allow all the other crews to continue racing. If a crew is able to catch and bump the boat which started 3 places in front of it, after the two in front have already bumped out, the crew is said to have ''over-bumped''. A crew which neither bumps a crew ahead nor is bumped by a crew behind before crossing the finishing post is said to have ''rowed over''.
After the race, any crew which bumps or over-bumps swaps places with the crew that it has bumped for the following day's racing. A crew which rows over stays in the same position. Crews finishing at the top of a division also :at the bottom of the next division, as the ''sandwich boat'', in an attempt to try to move up into the next division. The process is repeated over four days, allowing crews to move up or down several places in the overall order of boats. The finishing order of one year's May Bumps are then used as the starting order of the following year's races.

CCAT, Christ's, Clare Hall, Corpus Christi, Darwin, Girton, Homerton, Hughes Hall, King's, Magdalene, Peterhouse, Robinson, St. Catharine's, Selwyn, Sidney Sussex, St Edmund's, Wolfson, Addenbrooke's and the Veterinary School are the regular entrants never to have finished Head of the River for either the men's or women's events.
== Blades, Super-Blades, Technical Blades, and Spoons == Four boat 'awards' are informally/formally recognised by the individual college boat clubs that take part in the Cambridge May Bumps, these accolades are awarded as follows:
* Blades - The accolade of earning 'blades' (referring to the rowing oars used by crews) is given to crews that bump up on every day of the May bumps (alternately 4 bump ups for boats in the 'Sandwich Division'). Crews that achieve blades are often given the opportunity to purchase decoratory oars from their college boat club, to serve as a reminder of their contribution to the clubs success. For most college rowers, who do not attempt to become University Blues rowers, earning blades is the highest rowing related achievement that can be obtained. Obtaining blades is a rare occurrence. Crews who obtain blades are often photographed and recorded on the walls of the college boathouse to serve as a longer term reminder of their success, and to inspire future generations of college rowers. In the occasion that a crew earns blades, they also earn the right to row back to their college boathouse on the last day of the calendar with their college flag raised high; this practise allows for recognition of the (significant) achievement by members of other college boat clubs and the general public watching the races. * Super-Blades - In the event that a crew bumps and/or overbumps on the river 4 times (with no row overs/bumping down) they are said to have earned 'super-blades'. This is obviously a higher distinction that standard 'Blades' but is of course rarer due to the particularly circumstantial nature of the award, and the ability of the super-bladed crew that is required. * Technical Blades - In the case that a crew does not bump up on each day of rowing (at least), but does manage to bump up net 4 places in the overall standings over the course of the week, with no bumping down, i.e. 'making up' for any row overs with an overbump, then they are said to have qualified (at the discretion of the boatsperson at each college boat club) for 'Technical Blades'. Technical bladed rowers are usually afforded the same opportunity to obtain a ceremonial blade as those crews that obtain regular blades. * Spoons - This 'award' is obtained by crews that bump ''down'' on every day of the May bumps calendar. The awarding of spoons is an informal occasion by the crew captain, often this captain will actually buy a wooden spoon (decorated) for each crew member as a reminder that "at least they tried".
[[File:BladedCrew2018.jpg|alt=The Trinity Hall first men's crew obtains blades in the 2018 May Bumps.|center|thumb|1086x1086px|The Trinity Hall first men's crew obtains blades in the 2018 May Bumps.]]
== The Pegasus Cup == The '''Pegasus Cup''' is a Cambridge rowing prize first awarded in 2006. It was donated by [[Milton Brewery]] and will be awarded annually to the most successful college boat club competing in the Cambridge May Bumping Races. The winner is decided by means of a points system, which is described in the [[Cambridge University Combined Boat Club]] handbook as follows: [[File:PegasusCup.png|thumb|right|Pegasus Cup]] {{quote|The Cup is awarded to the Club gaining the most points over the course of the May Bumps. Points are awarded as follows: * One point for every place gained by each of a Club’s boats. * One point for each night that a Club retains the Men’s or Women’s Headship in Division One. * One point deducted for every place lost by each of a Club’s boats. The total number of points gained over the four days of racing is multiplied by 12 and then divided by the number of boats entered by the Club to give the final score.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cucbc.org/handbook/pegasus_cup|title=Pegasus Cup|work=CUCBC Handbook|publisher=CUCBC|accessdate=2009-06-05}}</ref>}}
To be eligible a club must have at least one men's and one women's boat (except in the case of single sex colleges where two boats of the same sex may be permitted).

Corrected the quote from Fonzie on Happy Days
revision.text:
{{unreferenced|date=July 2012}} {{for|the Hilltop Hoods song|The Nosebleed Section}}
In the [[United States]] and [[Canada]], the '''nosebleed section''' are the seats of a public area, usually an athletic [[stadium]] or [[gym]]nasium, that are highest and, usually, farthest from the desired activity. A common [[tongue-in-cheek]] reference to having seats at the upper tiers of a stadium is "sitting in the nosebleed section" or "nosebleed seats". The reference alludes to the propensity for [[nasal hemorrhage]] at [[high altitude]]s, usually owing to lower [[barometric pressure]].
The origin of the expression may have been the 1970s television series ''[[Happy Days]]''. Toward the end of one episode, [[Richie Cunningham]] (played by [[Ron Howard]]) and all his friends got to go to the JF&F concert, but the tickets were for seats way up top. Fonzie (played by [[Henry Winkler]]) uttered the words, "A guy could get a nosebleed up here". This seems to be the first documented popular use associating "nosebleed" with the way-up-high cheap seats at a spectator event.
==In popular culture==
[[Tom Petty]]'s song "Money Becomes King" refers to a performer's original fans having to sit "way up in the nosebleeds".
In the 109th episode of [[NBC]] sitcom [[Seinfeld]] ([[The Face Painter (Seinfeld episode)|The Face Painter]]), on being offered tickets for the Stanley Cup playoff game between the [[New York Rangers]] and the [[New Jersey Devils]] by Alec Berg, Jerry Seinfeld is told "If you don't mind the nose bleed section, they're yours".
In episode 22 of the first season of the [[NBC]] series [[Friday Night Lights (TV series)|Friday Night Lights]], running back [[Tim Riggins|Timothy Riggins]] after passing on a set of tickets to the Texas State Championship to a young family, the mother of whom he has been romantically acquainted, forgets that the tickets were originally promised to his former love interest [[Tyra Collette]]. Being as she made the trip to Dallas he provides her with four players' tickets with the caveat that "those are nosebleeds".
The Australian hip hop group [[Hilltop Hoods]] have a song titled "[[The Nosebleed Section]]". In the song, the meaning of nosebleed section is reversed to mean the front row. This is because when a person has a nosebleed, they are often instructed (incorrectly) to keep their head back and look straight up - as people are forced to do in the front row of a high-stage show.{{cn|date=April 2014}}
The band [[Imagine Dragons]] also have cited the expression with the meaning of a concert section in their song "[[Thunder (Imagine Dragons song)|Thunder]]". In the verse "Now I'm smiling from the stage, while you were clapping in the nosebleeds" they show they are the successful ones, while people who criticized them at an early age are now admiring them.
American rapper [[Post Malone]] used the expression in his song “[[White Iverson]]”. He says in his verse “Bitch I'm smiling, bet you see me from the nosebleeds”. This line refers to his happiness performing and the fact that people know him.
American rapper Kanye West uses this same expression in Gucci Mane's song "P**** Print" in which he is featured. "I can take you from nose bleeds to the floor seats" This line refers to the girls that he used to bang before he got with Kim Kardashian in which he would get all the p**** he wants in exchange for floor seats.
==See also== {{Wiktionary|nosebleed seat}} * [[Peanut gallery]] * [[The gods (theatrical)]] * [[Bleachers]]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Nosebleed Section}} [[Category:Stadiums]] [[Category:American English idioms]] [[Category:Seats]] [[Category:Sports venues]]

{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = People's Football Stadium | nickname = | image = | location = [[Karachi]], [[Sindh]], [[Pakistan]] | coordinates = {{coord|24|51|31|N|66|59|18|E|type:landmark_region:PK|display=it}} | broke_ground = 1988 | opened = 9 December 1995 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[City District Government Karachi]] | operator = City District Government Karachi | surface = Grass | Constructor = | construction_cost = USD 30.7 Million | area = {{convert|10|acre|m2}} | architect = | former_names = | nicknames = International Football Stadium | tenants = [[HBL FC]]
[[Karachi Football League]] (some games)
[[Pakistan national football team]] | seating_capacity = 40,000https://thekarachiwalla.com/2011/12/08/city-landmarks-peoples-stadium-lyari/ | dimensions = }} The '''Peoples Football Stadium''' is a football stadium located near [[Port Grand]], [[Karachi]], [[Sindh]], [[Pakistan]]. It is owned by the City District Government of Karachi. It has a capacity of 40,000. In 2016, [[Pakistan Army FC]] defeated [[PIA FC]] in the national football tournament at the stadium. https://tribune.com.pk/story/1070841/rangers-all-pakistan-football-tournament-rehman-hasnain-guide-army-to-title/ ==Overview== The stadium was built in 1988, and opened on 9 December 1995. It covers an area of {{convert|10|acre|m2}}. In 1999, when Prime Minister [[Benazir Bhutto]] came into power, new [[Floodlights (sport)|floodlights]] imported from [[France]] worth PKR 30.7 million were installed, to enable evening matches to take place. The [[Pakistan national football team]] moved to the Peoples Football Stadium from the [[Railway Stadium]] in [[Lahore]]. The stadium, hosted the [[SAFF Championship|South Asian Football Federation Championship]] in [[South Asian Football Federation Gold Cup 2005|2005]] which was won by [[India national football team|India]]. It also hosted all the matches in the inaugural [[Geo Super Football League]] in 2007. [[HBL FC]] who currently compete in the [[Pakistan Premier League]] play their homegames at the Peoples Football Stadium. ==References== {{reflist}} ==See also== * [[List of stadiums by capacity]] * [[List of stadiums in Pakistan]] * [[List of cricket grounds in Pakistan]] * [[List of sports venues in Karachi]] * [[List of sports venues in Lahore]] * [[List of sports venues in Faisalabad]] * [[List of association football stadiums by country#Pakistan|List of football stadiums]] * [[Pakistan Football Federation]] * [[Football in Pakistan]] == External links == * {{Official website|http://www.pff.com.pk|Pakistan Football Federation - official website}} {{Karachi topics}} [[Category:Football venues in Pakistan]] [[Category:Stadiums in Karachi]] [[Category:K-Electric F.C.]] {{Pakistan-sports-venue-stub}}

{{Infobox stadium | name = Rajamangala National Stadium
ราชมังคลากีฬาสถาน | fullname = Rajamangala National Stadium | image = Rajamangala Stadium Panorama.jpg | image_size = 300px | caption = | location = [[Bang Kapi District|Hua Mak, Bang Kapi]], [[Bangkok]], [[Thailand]] | coordinates = {{coord|13.755417|100.622167|format=dms|type:landmark_scale:3000}} | built = 22 September 1988 | opened = 1998 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = Sports Authority of Thailand (SAT) | architect = Faculty of Architecture, [[Chulalongkorn University]] | operator = Sports Authority of Thailand (SAT) | surface = Grass | construction_cost = | former_names = | tenants = [[Thailand national football team]] (1998–present) | capacity = 49,722 (all seated) | publictransit = {{rint|bangkok|airport}} [[Ramkhamhaeng Station (Airport Rail Link)|Ramkhamhaeng Station]]
{{rint|bangkok|Orange}} Rajamangala Stadium ''(from 2022)'' }} The '''Rajamangala National Stadium''' ({{lang-th|ราชมังคลากีฬาสถาน}}; {{RTGS|Ratchamangkhala Kila Sathan}}, {{IPA-th|râːt.t͡ɕʰā.māŋ.kʰā.lāː kīː.lāː sā.tʰǎːn|pron}}) is the national stadium of [[Thailand]] and the home stadium for the [[Thailand national football team]]. It is part of the [[Hua Mak Sports Complex]], and is located in Hua Mak Subdistrict, [[Bang Kapi District|Bang Kapi]], [[Bangkok]]. It officially opened in 1998. ==Overview== It was first used for the [[1998 Asian Games]] in 1998 and [[ASEAN University Games|1999 ASEAN University Games]] in 1999. Since then, it has been used for many international matches and football tournaments. Most notably, for the [[2007 AFC Asian Cup]]. Thai club sides have also used the stadium when playing in continental cup competitions. Krung Thai Bank FC (now [[Bangkok Glass FC]]) used it for [[AFC Champions League]] matches, and [[PEA FC]] and [[Chonburi FC]] have recently used it in the [[AFC Cup]]. Aside from football, it has been used for athletics, pop concerts and political rallies. Rajamangala Stadium was designed by the Faculty of Architecture at [[Chulalongkorn University]]. The main material used in construction was concrete and therefore, though the stadium is impressive and imposing, it could never be described as beautiful. However, it is undoubtedly dramatic. The stands rise and fall like a giant, exaggerated version of Huddersfield's [[Galpharm Stadium]]. At each end are quite narrow tiers of seats but the tiers rise and rise as they move round the sides until they peak level with the half-way line. From an aesthetic point of view, the stadium is best viewed from a distance, preferably from the air, where the elliptical shape of the side tribunes seems particularly pronounced. The aforementioned side tribunes are designated 'East' and 'West'. 'East' is the uncovered popular side; 'West' is the covered side where the more expensive seats are. The two ends are designated 'North' and 'South'. 'North' is the more popular of the two. It's where the more vocal and colourful elements of the Thai support congregate. The capacity of the stadium is 65,000. When the stadium first opened the capacity was 80,000. But plastic seats were installed on the North, South and East sides, where previously there had been bare concrete steps, in readiness for the 2007 AFC Asian Cup. The stadium is not served by public transport which has always been a source of frustration for fans. No [[Bangkok Skytrain]]s, subway-trains or normal overground trains stop anywhere near the stadium (unlike at the [[National Stadium (Thailand)|National Stadium]], which is served by the Skytrain - [[National Stadium BTS station]]). However, there are buses and taxis which pass fairly close to the stadium. In 2010 [[Airport Rail Link (Bangkok)|Airport Rail Link]] was completed which means that the stadium is served by the City Line at - [[Ramkhamhaeng Station (Airport Rail Link)|Ramkhamhaeng Station]]. From 2022 [[MRT Orange Line]] will be open and Rajamangala Stadium Station will be located in front of the stadium. The stadium hosted the 2012 [[Race of Champions]]. On 24 November 2013, a crowd estimated at 100,000 joined the rally around Bangkok's Democracy Monument in an anti-government protest, according to the Democrat Party, as pro-government red shirts gathered at Rajamangala Sports Stadium. Other stadiums in Bangkok include the [[Thai Army Sports Stadium]], the [[Thai-Japanese Stadium]] and [[Chulalongkorn University Stadium]]. ==Performances== ===Past performances=== *[[Carabao (band)|Carabao]] 15 Year Celebrate-Made in Thailand Concert - 25 December 1999บันทึกการแสดงคอนเสิร์ต 15 ปี เมด อิน ไทยแลนด์ *[[Bakery Music|B]] - Day Concert - 10 December 2004 *Bangkok Music Festival - 7 May 2005 *[[Asanee-Wasan]] Rumrai Concert - 17 November 2007 *YAMAHA Presents [[S.M. Entertainment|SMTOWN]] Live’08 in Bangkok - 7 February 2009 *Show King M Bangkok - 6 April 2010 *Soda Chang Presents [[Bodyslam (band)|Bodyslam]] Live In Kraam By Air Asia - 27 November 2010{{cite web|url=http://www.mediavision1994.com/video_detail2.php?videoid=39|title=สุดยอดความมัน และความอลังการของระบบภาพ เสียง และแสง กับคอนเสิร์ต "BODYSLAM LIVE IN คราม " สะกดสายตา กว่า 65000 คู่ ณ ราชมังคลากีฬาสถาน..." |publisher=[[Media Vision(Thai)]]|date=2010-11-20}} *Korean Music Wave in Bangkok presented by JL Starnet - 12 March 2011 *Bangkok Summer Festival By Coca-Cola - 7–8 May 2011 *MBC Korean Music Wave in Bangkok 2012 - 7 April 2012 *[[Lady Gaga]] [[Born This Way Ball Tour]] - 25 May 2012 *M! Countdown Smile-Thailand - 11 October 2012 *Race of Champions - 14–16 December 2012 *The Voice Thailand "True Sound Real Sound" - 2 March 2013 *[[One Direction]] [[On the Road Again Tour]] - 14 March 2015{{cite web|title=One Direction Announce 'On The Road Again' Tour Dates {{!}} MTV UK|url=http://www.mtv.co.uk/one-direction/news/one-direction-announce-on-the-road-again-tour-dates|website=MTV UK|language=en}} * [[Coldplay]] [[A Head Full of Dreams Tour]] - 7 April 2017 {{cite web|title=COLDPLAY ANNOUNCES ASIAN TOUR FOR APRIL 2017 JUST ADDED NEW STADIUM SHOW IN THAILAND|url=http://www.bectero.com/en/news/news-concert-event/coldplay-announces-asian-tour-for-april-2017-just-added-new-stadium-show-in-thailand|website=www.bectero.com|accessdate=9 April 2017}} ===Upcoming performances=== *[[BTS (band)|BTS]] World Tour: [[BTS World Tour: Love Yourself|Love Yourself]] - 6 April 2019 *[[Ed Sheeran]] [[÷ Tour]] - 28 April 2019 ==Tournament results== The stadium has hosting several international FIFA matches.
